title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify a forest likely to be present between 30 and 50 degrees north or south of the equator as temperate forest or temperate wet forest.
The response identifies a forest likely to be present between 30 and 50 degrees north or south of the equator as temperate forest or temperate wet forest.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the rate of cycling of carbon is faster in a temperate wet forest than in a boreal forest, such as any of the following:

· There would be higher rates of cycling of carbon in a temperate wet forest than in a boreal forest because there are higher rates of photosynthesis/respiration/productivity/decomposition resulting from the warmer temperatures and higher rates of precipitation in the wet forest.

· Carbon cycling in boreal forests will occur at a lower rate than in temperate wet forests because there are lower rates of photosynthesis/respiration/productivity/decomposition in boreal forests due to colder temperatures and less precipitation.

The response explains why the rate of cycling of carbon is faster in a temperate wet forest than in a boreal forest, such as one of the following:

· There would be higher rates of cycling of carbon in a temperate wet forest than in a boreal forest because there are higher rates of photosynthesis/respiration/productivity/decomposition resulting from the warmer temperatures and higher rates of precipitation in the wet forest.

· Carbon cycling in boreal forests will occur at a lower rate than in temperate wet forests because there are lower rates of photosynthesis/respiration/productivity/decomposition in boreal forests due to colder temperatures and less precipitation.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim based on evidence in the graph to support or refute the statement that a tundra ecosystem may only support 1 species of reptiles, but a desert ecosystem of a similar size may support 59 species of reptiles such as the following:

· Reptiles are cold-blooded (ectothermic) and require a warm to hot climate. The temperatures in the tundra will not support most cold-blooded species (ectotherms). Cold blooded species will thrive in the heat of most deserts.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how a species of bird on a remote island could have acquired the adaptation of ground nesting, such as any of the following:

· If there are no predators present, there will be no selective pressure to nest in trees, so there will be more birds that build nests on the ground.

· It is energetically more efficient to nest on the ground, so the birds that build nests on the ground are better suited to the environment.

· There is less risk that eggs will be damaged in a storm.

The response explains how a species of bird on a remote island could have acquired the adaptation of ground nesting, such as one of the following:

· It is energetically more efficient to nest on the ground, so the birds that build nests on the ground are better suited to the environment.

· There is less risk that eggs will be damaged in a storm.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why a hydroelectric power plant is more likely to be constructed in a mountainous temperate forest than in a flat temperate grassland, such as any of the following:

· Temperate forests receive more rain than savannas, providing more water to generate hydroelectricity.

· Mountains also have steeper slopes that generate more runoff; this increased flow will help to generate hydroelectricity.

· Mountains have more valleys that make more suitable dam sites.

The response explains why a hydroelectric power plant is more likely to be constructed in a mountainous temperate forest than in a flat temperate grassland, such as one of the following:

· Temperate forests receive more rain than savannas, providing more water to generate hydroelectricity.

· Mountains also have steeper slopes that generate more runoff; this increased flow will help to generate hydroelectricity.

· Mountains have more valleys that make more suitable dam sites.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim using evidence that supports or refutes the claim proposed by researchers that fields that include non-native species usually have greater biodiversity than fields with only native plants, such as any of the following:

· This claim is refuted because non-native species often out compete native species and fewer native plant species can survive. This impacts the number and type of herbivores/animals that can be supported in the area.

· This claim is supported because biodiversity includes all species, native and non-native, and an increase in the number and type of plant species will increase plant biodiversity, which should increase animal biodiversity.

The response makes a claim using evidence that supports or refutes the claim proposed by researchers that fields that include non-native species usually have greater biodiversity than fields with only native plants, such as one of the following:

· This claim is refuted because non-native species often out compete native species and fewer native plant species can survive. This impacts the number and type of herbivores/animals that can be supported in the area.

· This claim is supported because biodiversity includes all species, native and non-native, and an increase in the number and type of plant species will increase plant biodiversity, which should increase animal biodiversity.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify the independent variable in the experiment, such as any of the following:

· The length of time that the trees had been established in the environment

· The location of leaf litter collection

· The level of forest management practiced

title: Part I
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the effect that nutrient levels in soil would likely have on the results of the investigation, such as any of the following:

· Increased nutrient levels in the soil would increase plant growth and increase the amount of leaf litter and the insect populations at the sites.

· Decreased nutrient levels in the soil would decrease plant growth and decrease the amount of leaf litter and insect populations at the sites.

The response describes the effect that nutrient levels in soil would likely have on the results of the investigation, such as one of the following:

· Increased nutrient levels in the soil would increase plant growth and increase the amount of leaf litter and the insect populations at the sites.

· Decreased nutrient levels in the soil would decrease plant growth and decrease the amount of leaf litter and insect populations at the sites.

title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how modifying the experiment to collect samples from areas with grass litter and areas with tree litter could alter the results of the experiment, such as any of the following:

· Tree litter is more diverse than grass litter, which means tree litter provides more habitat variety for insects than grass litter.

· If the area studied is a lawn with a monoculture of grass, there would be likely be less biodiversity than in an area with a variety of trees. The monoculture would reduce the quality and variety of litter for insects.

· The area with grass litter may be more exposed to sunlight and drier. Less moisture would support fewer insects and lower diversity of insect species.

· Some insect species may prefer the conditions provided by grass litter.

The response explains how modifying the experiment to collect samples from areas with grass litter and areas with tree litter could alter the results of the experiment, such as one of the following:

· Tree litter is more diverse than grass litter, which means tree litter provides more habitat variety for insects than grass litter.

· If the area studied is a lawn with a monoculture of grass, there would be likely be less biodiversity than in an area with a variety of trees. The monoculture would reduce the quality and variety of litter for insects.

· The area with grass litter may be more exposed to sunlight and drier. Less moisture would support fewer insects and lower diversity of insect species.

· Some insect species may prefer the conditions provided by grass litter.
